questions.question: An 18-month-old child is brought to OPD with complaints of blood in his urine. Examinationreveals a non-tender mass in the left flank that does not cross the midline. Blood pressure isalso found to be elevated. Imaging reveals a left renal tumor and surgical resection isplanned. The gross appearance of the mass is shown below. What is the likely diagnosis?
Which of the following statements is true regarding Wilms tumor?

options.A: It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder
options.B: It is associated with MIC-2 gene expression
options.C: It is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13
options.D: The most common presentation is hematuria818

questions.explanation: Wilms' tumor is associated with the deletion of chromosome 11p13.It is an autosomal-dominant disorder. The most common clinical presentation is an abdominalmass.Note: MIC-2 gene expression is seen in neuroblastoma.

questions.question: In patients with Wilms tumors, which of the following microscopic features are indicative ofresistance to chemotherapy?
questions.explanation: In Wilms' tumor, the presence of anaplasia is indicative of resistance to chemotherapy.This correlates with the presence of TP53 mutations and, hence, is associated with a poorprognosis.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor?
questions.explanation: Anaplastic histology is the most important prognostic factor in Wilms' tumor.It is seen in about 5% of cases and is characterized by the presence of cells with large,hyperchromatic, pleomorphic nuclei, and abnormal mitoses. It is associated with TP53 mutationsand resistance to chemotherapy.Anaplasia is uncommon in children < 2 years. Hence, tumors presenting at an young age have asignificantly better prognosis than those presenting in older children.Prognostic factors in Wilms' tumor include:Favorable prognosisHistologic typeClassic triphasic componenAdverse prognosisAnaplastic histologytTumor stageLowHighMolecular alterationSAge of onset11q deletion16q deletionGainof chromosome 1q>2 years<2 years

questions.question: Which of the following is not associated with Wilms tumor?
questions.explanation: Bilateral polycystic kidneys are not associated with Wilms tumor.827Wilms' tumor can be associated with:• Aniridia - WAGR syndrome•Gonadal dysgenesis - Denys-Drash syndrome• Hemihypertrophy and omphalocele - Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome

questions.question: A 16-year-old girl is being evaluated for a history of recurrent seizures and abdominaldiscomfort. Examination reveals the following nail findings. Which of the following shouldshe be screened for?819
questions.explanation: This clinical scenario and image showing periungual fibromas are strongly suggestive of tuberoussclerosis. This condition is associated with renal angiomyolipomas (present in 25-50% of cases).Tuberous sclerosis is a multisystem disorder that has an autosomal dominant mode ofinheritance. The mutations are involved in the TSC1 gene that encodes hamartin on chromosome9 and the TSC2 gene that encodes a protein tuberin on chromosome 16.The clinical features of tuberous sclerosis include:• Skin lesions -.• Hypomelanotic ash leaf-type macules• Periungual fibromas or Koenen tumors (small fibromas or nodules of skin around fingernails ortoenails)• Shagreen patch- roughened, raised lesion with an orange-peel consistency, primarily in thelumbosacral region• Facial angiofibromas• Confetti skin lesions• Neurological features -•••Epilepsy and intellectual disability (due to cortical tubers)Autism spectrum disorderSubependymal giant cell astrocytomas• Other tumors -• Cardiac rhabdomyoma• Renal angiomyolipomas, renal cysts• Pulmonary lymphangioleiomyomatosisAngiomyolipoma is a benign renal neoplasm (hamartoma) originating from perivascularepithelioid cells (PEComa). It consists of vessels, smooth muscle, and fat in variable proportions.They are highly susceptibility to spontaneous hemorrhage.The histological image of renal angiomyolipoma is given below:828Renal AngiomyolipomaRenal AngiomyolipomaBlood vesselsAdipocytesSmoothmuscle

questions.question: A 50-year-old diabetic patient is being evaluated for chronic abdominal discomfort. CECT ofthe abdomen and pelvis shows a heterogeneously enhancing renal mass with a central stellatescar. On resection, the tumor appears mahogany brown. What is the site of origin of thistumor?
questions.explanation: The given clinical history is suggestive of renal oncocytoma. It arises from the intercalated cells ofthe collecting ducts.It is a benign epithelial neoplasm. Grossly, these tumors appear tan or mahoganybrown and relatively homogeneous. They are usually well encapsulated with a central scar inone-third of cases.Microscopically, they are composed of large eosinophilic cells having small, round,benign-appearing nuclei that have large nucleoli. Ultrastructurally, these eosinophilic cells havenumerous mitochondria.The gross and histological appearances of renal oncocytoma are shown in the images given below:829Renal OncocytomaRenal OncocytomaEosinophilic cells withlarge, round nuclei830Oncocytes refer to epithelial cells with abundant eosinophilic granular cytoplasm (due to theaccumulation of mitochondria). They can arise in various tissues and are referred to as:••Hurthle cells/Ashkenazy cells in the thyroid glandOxyphilic cells in the parotid gland• Apocrine metaplasia in the breast

questions.question: Which of the following is the most important determinant of malignant potential in thepapillary type of renal tumor?
questions.explanation: The most important determinant of malignant potential in the papillary type of renal tumor is thesize of the tumor.The papillary type of renal tumors includes:• Renal papillary adenoma (≤ 1.5 cm)•Papillary type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC) -> 1.5 cmSmall renal papillary growths are fairly common and incidentally found. Ruling out of malignancyis one of the processes carried out during the evaluation of donor transplant kidneys.Renal Papillary AdenomaPapillary architecture (Nipple-like projections)Papillary renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the second most common type of renal cell carcinoma andit arises from proximal tubules. It can be multifocal or bilateral. It is typically hemorrhagic andcystic, especially when large.It is often a circumscribed tumor composed of papillae formed by delicate fibrovascular cores thatoften contain foamy macrophages and Psammoma bodies.It has two histological types:• Type 1 papillary RCC - single layer of cells on the basement membrane and low-grade nuclearfeatures831• Type 2 papillary RCC - pseudostratification of cells and usually has high-grade nuclear features

questions.question: The following image shows a nephrectomy specimen of a patient diagnosed with renal cellcarcinoma. What is the likely histopathological finding in this tumor?

options.C: Small cells with high N/C ratio

questions.explanation: The given image shows a bright yellow variegated mass distorting the renal outline at the lowerpole. This is suggestive of the clear cell type of renal cell carcinoma (RCC). The yellow color is dueto prominent lipid accumulation.Gross findings of various types of renal tumors:Clear-cell RCCPapillary RCCChromophobe RC OncocytomaAngiomyolipomaCSite of Proximal tubularoriginProximal tubuleIntercalated cellsepitheliumof collecting ductIntercalated cellsof collecting ductPerivascular epithelioid cells (PECSSoma)NumberColorCapsuleSolitary, globular,unilateralGolden yellow, due to the high lipid content of theircellsPseudocapsule+Multifocal and bil Solitary, unilatera Usually solitaryateralGrey tan to darkbrown,dependingon the degree ofintratumoral hemorrhagePseudocapsule+1Light tan to browMahogany brownnVariegated, friablCircumscribed but unencapsulatedHomogenousWell encapsulatedHomogenousysts, necrosis, heemorrhagic fociAppear Variegated with canceMostly solitary, can be multifocalYellow to pinkish-tan, depending on the relative proportions of the various componentsCircumscribed but unencapsulatedVariable

questions.question: The nephrectomy specimen of a tumor of a 40-year-old man shows the following histologicalpresentation. Which of the following familial cancer syndromes is this condition associatedwith?821

options.B: Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome

questions.explanation: The given image shows eosinophilic cells with prominent cell membranes and perinuclear halo,which is suggestive of chromophobe cell renal cell carcinoma (RCC). It is associatedwith Birt-Hogg-Dubé syndrome.Other familial cancer syndromes and the common malignancies associated with them are:• Hereditary leiomyomatosis and renal cell cancer syndrome - papillary RCC• Large cells with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large nuclei, and prominent inclusion-likeeosinophilic nucleoli.⚫ Tuberous sclerosis clear-cell RCC••-⚫ Von Hippel-Lindau syndrome (VHL) - clear-cell RCCThe image given below shows the histology of chromophobe cell RCC.832Chromophobe Cell Renal Cell CarcinomaChromophobe Cell Renal Cell CarcinomaPale eosinophiliccellsPerinuclear halo

questions.question: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma is matched incorrectly with itsrespective cytogenetic patterns?

options.C: Hereditary papillary RCC - loss of Y
options.D: Sporadic papillary RCC - loss of Y

questions.explanation: Loss of Y chromosome is a feature of sporadic papillary carcinoma, not hereditary papillary RCC.833Cytogenetic patterns in renalcell carcinoma (RCC)RRSporadic papillary RCCTrisomy 7, 17- Loss of Y- Mutated.activated METHereditary papillary RCC- Trisomy 7- Mutated.activated METRRSporadic clear cell RCCHereditary clear cell RCCLoss of sequences on chromosome 3- Loss of VHL gene- Inactivated, mutated VHL geneHypermethylation of VHL geneOMARROWVarious types of renal carcinoma and their cytogenetic abnormalities are given below:• Papillary renal cell carcinoma -••••Sporadic type trisomies 7 and 17, loss of Y chromosome-Familial type trisomy 7 (mapped to MET gene)Clear-cell renal-cell carcinoma (whether familial, sporadic, or associated with VHL syndrome)• Loss of sequences on the short arm of chromosome 3, which harbors the VHL gene

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation: Clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is the most common histological subtype of renal cell carcinoma,accounting for 70% to 80% of renal cell cancers.It is most likely to arise from the proximal tubular epithelium as solitary lesions. It has acharacteristic tendency to invade the renal vein. The histological features are:• Rounded or polygonal tumor cells• Abundant clear or granular cytoplasm, which contains glycogen and lipids• Arranged in a solid to trabecular (cordlike) or tubular patternThe histological appearance of clear-cell renal cell carcinoma is shown in the image given below:834Clear Cell Carcinoma (RCC)Clear Cell Carcinoma (RCC)Rounded or polygonalcellsAbundant clearcytoplasmNote: The Furhman nuclear grading system was previously used for histological grading of RCC(except chromophobe RCC). It is now replaced by the WHO/International Society of UrologicPathology (ISUP) grading system.

questions.question: Which of the following tumors does not have papillary architecture on histopathology?
questions.explanation: Succinate dehydrogenase (SDH)-deficient renal cell carcinoma does not show papillaryarchitecture. It is associated with a bubbly appearance of histopathology.It is a malignant epithelial tumor associated with germline mutations in the SDH gene. Itis composed of vacuolated, eosinophilic-clear cells arranged in a solid, nested, or tubular pattern.The presence of the vacuoles imparts the characteristic bubbly appearance, as shown below.835SDH-Deficient Renal Cell CarcinomaSDH-Deficient Renal Cell CarcinomaVacuolated cellsBubbly appearanceRenal cell carcinoma subtypes with papillary architecture in histology:• Papillary renal cell carcinoma• Hereditary leiomyomatosis renal cell carcinoma• Xp11 translocation renal cell carcinoma.Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma

questions.question: Which of the following subtypes of renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having aplant-cell-like appearance with a perinuclear halo on histological examination?
questions.explanation: Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma shows large cells having plant-cell-like appearance with aperinuclear halo.They are arranged in solid sheets with a concentration of the largest cells around blood vessels.836Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma can differentiated from oncocytoma and clear cell RCC asfollows:•Oncocytoma does not show perinuclear halo whereas chromophobe RCC shows perinuclear halo⚫ CK7 is diffusely positive in chromophobe RCC but it is negative in clear-cell RCC.Chromophobe RCC cannot be histologically graded because of its innate nuclear atypia.The histological image of chromophobe renal cell carcinoma is given below:

questions.question: A patient with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is found to have a renal tumor and malignancy issuspected. Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding the renal tumorassociated with this condition?

options.A: It constitutes 5% of all renal tumors
options.B: Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses
options.D: It arises from the intercalated cells of the collecting duct

questions.explanation: The renal tumor commonly associated with Birt-Hogg-Dube syndrome is chromophobe renal cellcarcinoma (RCC). It has an excellent prognosis.It constitutes 5% of all renal carcinomas. It arises from the intercalated cells of the collectingduct. Cytogenetic testing of the tumor shows multiple chromosomal losses and extremehypodiploidy.The histological image of chromophobe RCC is given below:837

questions.question: Which of the following tumors characteristically shows a hobnail pattern on microscopy?
questions.explanation: Collecting duct carcinoma or Bellini duct carcinoma shows a characteristic hobnail pattern andprominent desmoplastic stroma on microscopy.The hobnail pattern refers to the bulbous nuclear projections of epithelial cells that protrude intothe lumen as little bumps. It is associated with tubular, tubulopapillary, or tubulocystic pattern.Collecting duct carcinoma arises from the principal cells of the renal collecting ducts ofBellini. The majority of these tumors are associated with poor outcome, due to their highlyaggressive clinical course.The histological section showing collecting duct carcinoma with the characteristic hobnail patternis given below:Renal Collecting Duct / Bellini Duct Carcinoma838Renal Collecting Duct / Bellini Duct CarcinomaIrregular channels lined byhighly atypical epitheliumHobnail pattern bulbous nuclear projections ofepithelial cells that protrude into the lumen as little bumpsNote: The hobnail pattern is also seen in clear cell carcinoma of the ovary.

questions.question: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing which of the following?
questions.explanation: Individuals with the sickle cell trait are at a higher risk of developing medullary renal cellcarcinoma.It is a rare, highly aggressive neoplasm and is morphologically similar to collecting ductcarcinoma.The hypoxic microenvironment in the renal medulla created by hyperosmolarity, low pH, andstasis enhances red blood sickling and ischemic damage. This leads to chronic regenerativeproliferation of medullary epithelium and activation of hypoxia-induced signalingpathways, which in turn promote neoplastic change.The histological section of renal medullary carcinoma showing prominent cytological atypia isshown below:839Renal Medullary CarcinomaRenal Medullary CarcinomaProminent cytological atypia

questions.question: A pathologist is studying the histopathological slide from a nephrectomy specimen from apatient with renal carcinoma. He observes neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm and papillaryarchitecture. Which of the following subtypes of renal carcinoma is this likely to be?
questions.explanation: Xp11 translocation carcinoma contains neoplastic cells with clear cytoplasm with a papillaryarchitecture on histopathology. It is also associated with Psammoma bodies.This condition is caused by translocations of the TFE3 gene located on Xp11.2, which results inoverexpression of the TFE3 transcription factor. It often occurs in young patients and isassociated with a poor prognosis.The histological section of Xp11 translocation carcinoma is given below:840Xp11 Translocation CarcinomaXp11 Translocation CarcinomaPapillary architectureCells with clearcytoplasm

questions.question: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding renal cell carcinoma?

options.A: It can invade the renal vein
options.C: It may arise from the proximal convoluted tubule

questions.explanation: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is more common among males, with a male to female ratio of 2:1.Renal cell carcinoma may arise from the proximal convoluted tubules (PCT). The classical clinicalfeatures of renal cell carcinoma are costovertebral pain, palpable mass, and painless hematuria. Itcharacteristically invades the renal vein and has a high tendency for distant metastasis.Paraneoplastic manifestations of renal cell carcinoma include:•Polycythemia• Hypercalcemia• Hypertension• Hepatic dysfunction841• Feminization or masculinization• Cushing syndrome⚫ Eosinophilia• Leukemoid reactions• Amyloidosis

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma?
questions.explanation: The most common site of metastasis in renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is the lung (more than 50%).Common sites of metastasis of renal cell carcinoma in descending order are:•• Lungs•-Bones osteolytic lesions•Regional lymph nodes• Liver• Adrenals•⚫ Brain

questions.question: Which of the following types of renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis?
questions.explanation: Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma has the worst prognosis of all renal cell carcinoma subtypes.The renal cell carcinoma subtypes with poor prognosis in descending order are•⚫ Collecting duct renal cell carcinoma• Medullary renal cell carcinoma• Clear cell renal cell carcinomaChromophobe renal cell carcinoma has the best prognosis.

questions.question: Which of the following genes is not mutated in familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes?
questions.explanation: WT gene is mutated in Wilms' tumor, not renal cell carcinoma.The following gene mutations are associated with familial renal cell carcinoma syndromes:• C-met proto-oncogene•Fumarate hydratase gene• BHD gene• VHL gene842• TSC1 gene• PTEN gene

questions.question: Which of the following pairs correctly describes the immunohistochemical property of renalcell carcinoma in a cancer of unknown origin?
questions.explanation: Renal cell carcinoma is CK7 negative and CK20 negative.The most common subtype of renal cell carcinoma is clear-cell renal cell carcinoma, which is CK7negative. Therefore, in determining the origin of cancer of unknown primary,immunohistochemistry (IHC) expression of renal cell carcinoma will generally be CK7 negativeand CK20 negative. Chromophobe renal cell carcinoma and papillary renal cell carcinoma arepositive for CK7.843
